PROJECT PREPARATORY  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  Project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required to complete due diligence 
for the ensuing project. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The  objective  of  the  PPTA  is  to  design  an  investment  project  for  improved  water 
resources management and enhanced productivity of irrigated agriculture in the project area. 
The TA will include the following key activities:

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  PPTA is estimated to cost $1,670,000 equivalent, of which $1,500,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The 
Government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation and facilities, whose value is estimated to account for 10% of the total PPTA 
cost. The detailed cost estimate to be financed by ADB’s TASF-Others is presented in Table 2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  PPTA will provide a total of 32 international and 67 national person-months of consulting 
services (Table 3). ADB will recruit the TA consultants' team through a firm using the QCBS 
procedure at 80:20 ratio and full technical proposals following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and its Borrowers (2010, as amended from time to time).

6.  The outline terms of reference for the key PPTA consultants are described in paragraphs 
7 to 9.  
 
7.  Water Resources Specialist/Team Leader (international, 8.0 person-months [p-m]) 
and Deputy Team Leader/Irrigation Engineer (national, 12 p-m). They will provide overall 
direction, manage PPTA relationships with MAWR, ADB and other stakeholders, to ensure 
effective coordination and synergies between all concerned, as well as managing all experts’ 
inputs, activities and outputs, ensuring the quality of the initial system wide planning exercises 
and ensuing feasibility study and report. They will lead the development of subproject selection 
criteria and the identification of subprojects, the comprehensive review of the entire selected 
irrigation  systems  including  water  balance  assessments,  identifying  and  quantifying  major 
problem areas inherent to systems. Based on the above, propose priority R&M interventions for 
the systems.    
 
8.  Irrigation and Drainage Engineer (international, 5 p-m; national, 7 p-m). In each I&D 
system, they will: (i) identify and quantify water balance, waterlogging, and soil salinity causes, 
extent, severity, trends and impacts; (ii) assess climate change impacts, and recommend policy 
and investment options on how to adopt climate change impacts; (iii) review in detail existing 
I&D practice, identifying bottlenecks arising at the main, inter-farm, and on-farm I&D levels; (iv) 
undertake detailed studies to breakdown and quantify the irrigated command served from the 
pumping plants in each selected irrigation systems; (v) based on current and projected future 
cropping patterns determine the consumptive use and crop water requirement for each crop to 
be  grown  and  the  total  requirements  represented  by  the  patterns  and  using  reliable 
assumptions/estimates of irrigation and conveyance efficiencies; and (vi) identify, design, and 
estimate the cost for I&D improvement packages.  
 
9.  Pumping Plant Specialists (international, 4 p-m; national, [electrical, 4.5 p-m, and 
mechanical, 4.5 pm, pumping plant-power, 2.0 p-m]). They will: (i) assess the condition of

the  pump  stations,  including  motors,  suction  piping,  valves,  cooling  system,  rising  mains, 
electrical control and power supply works as well as pump house structures; (ii) formulate a 
recommendation  to  either  rehabilitate  and  upgrade  or  to  replace  the  pumping  plants;  (iii) 
formulate R&M plan with feasibility level designs and with the cost estimations for the pumping 
stations; (iv) with the Procurement Specialist, prepare model bid documents for R&M of the 
initial  pumping  station  or  stations,  including  the  required  drawings,  data  sheets  and 
specifications, and carry out an initial bidding process through ICB for pump station R&M.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  MAWR will be the PPTA executing agency. The Deputy Minister in charge of water 
resources  at  MAWR  will  serve  as  Project  Director  and  provide  overall  guidance  to  TA 
implementation. MAWR will also appoint: (i) a PPTA coordinator in the MAWR in Tashkent to 
facilitate communication between ADB, the PPTA consultants, Project Director, and counterpart 
staff in Tashkent and in the field on day-to-day implementation matters: and (ii) three full-time 
counterpart staff (Pump Engineer, O&M Engineer, and an Economist) each from Amu-Surkhan 
BISA in Surkhandarya Province and three BISAs (i.e. Naryn-Karadarya,  Naryn-Syrdarya, and 
Syrdarya-Sokh) in Fergana Valley to provide necessary support to the PPTA team in the field 
with Government financing. A PPTA Steering Committee chaired by Deputy Minister in charge 
of water resources at MAWR, with representation from the ministries of economy; finance; 
environment; and foreign economic relations, investment, and trade as well as appropriate local 
representation will be established prior to commencement of PPTA activities to review PPTA 
progress and outputs and meet and render project-specific decisions as necessary.1 MAWR will 
also provide the following with Government financing: (i) adequate office space in Tashkent, 
Surkhandarya, and Fergana Valley as required for the PPTA team; (ii) telephone, heating, 
electricity, and water; (iii) logistical support during the field visits, access to project sites and 
other facilities; (iv) available data and feasibility studies as required; and (v) facilitation of 
workshops.  All disbursements under the PPTA will be made in accordance with the Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended). 
 
11.  The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table 4.   
 
Table 4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date

1 A Procurement Committee within MAWR will be authorized, in accordance with local regulations, to review and 
endorse: (i) a shortlist of consultants for an ensuing loan project; (ii) proposals for consultancy contract; (iii) draft 
bidding  documents,  and  draft  contracts  for  pumping  plant  rehabilitation  under  the  loan  project;  (iv)  other 
procurement documents produced under the TA that would require government endorsement.
